text: Several oz. pour from a bottle; thanks to falco242. Consumed on 8-30-16. Pours dark brown with a moderate amount of beige head. Suspended particulate. Lightly roasted aroma. Dry, pleasant smell. Chemical, medicinal flavor in a good way. Roasted malts. Earthy flavor. Really nice. One of the tastiest beers Ive had in a long time. Nice and lively palate effects. Perfectly executed, complex, and interesting. Im a big fan. Reminds me of a smallr Surly Blakkr.

On tap at SLL tasting. Pours a deep black with a big brown head that fades 3/4 moderately fast and then stalls, leaving a lumpy thick sheet with heavy lacing. Lots of fine carbonation. Smell is roasty, piney, tropical, clean and fresh. Taste is heavy roast bitterness, moderate coffee flavor, strong bitter piney finish. Mouthfeel is dry and resinous.

Bottle. Deep brown/black body. Frothy beige head. Aroma of chocolate, grapefruit, roasted malts, pine, cocoa, citrus. The flavor is lightly to moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture, moderate to lively carbonation. Nice balance of roasted malts, bitter hops, chocolate, resin, charcoal. Lingering bitterness. Clean.

Sample at WOBFest 2016. Another hit by Maine brewing. Excellent beer with a whole lot going on. Very malty and hits you with some chocolate flavor, then theres citrus and finally theres some coffee at the end. Kind of like a three-course meal and dessert in a single sip.

Pours an opaque brownish black on tap with fluffy tan head that dissipates to leave good lacing. Aroma of big piney hops and lots of strong chocolate malt and a hint of earthy roast. Taste is even more toward the pine and chocolate, less roast, mild bitterness. Right along the style, solid beer.

Bottle from a friend. Black color, beige head. Bitter taste with roasted malts, nuts, coffee, chocolate, licorice, pine and hops. Bitter finish with coffee, licorice, pine, hops, nuts and roasted malts. Exquisite black IPA.

Appearance- almost stout in appearance
Aroma-roasted malt in character with a subtle hop presence
Taste- roasted dark ale with malt characteristic bordering on a stout/porter with a late hop presence that balances the smooth malt with a slightly bitter mouth feel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

dark brown pour long lasting orange brown cream head. Aroma roasted caramel, coffee, woody carob. Tastes smooth carob some citrus hops, dry stout characteristics with thicker creamy body. Super smooth coffee flavor. Chocolate with a tangy hint of carob, peaches. lacks the uncouth astringency of inferior BIPAs. This one restores my faith in the style. EXCELLENT.

Refrigerated 0.5 L brown bottle, bottled March 11, 2016 poured into a glass. Black with big beige/light brown head. Aroma is herbal hops & dark malt, medium body, medium carbonation, and some lacing. Taste is roasted malt, chocolate, herbal hops, some anise, some pine hops, and dry finish.  Pretty heavy, flavorful, but just not for me.

$7.29 bomber, Wine Warehouse. Pours black with a large light brown, smooth, soft, fluffy head. Beautiful hoppy nose: citrus and pine, along with roasted malts, nuts, light coffee. Flavor is thinner than the nose: light flavors of peach and mango, along with a bit of citrus peel and pine. Slight coffee and chocolate tinge as well.
Pours a brown color with a foamy cream colored head. Notes of roasted nuts, milk chocolate, orange citrus, and brown sugar. Nice beer really well balanced.

July 22, 2015. On tap at the brewery. 
Black with a small off-white head. Aroma is sweet licorice, notes of roasted coffee, dark chocolate, pine, grass and peach. Taste is light to medium sweet with licorice, toffee and peach. Crisp bitter roasted finish with pine and grass and hints of sweet licorice. Medium bodied, average carbonation.
Bottle. Very chocolaty and also with notes of coffee, orange, citrus and hay. A bit creamy. Soft and light mouthfeel.

Bottle. 
Pours black with a tan head. 
Aroma of chocolate and licorice. 
Smooth brew with a taste of roasted malts and chocolate. A bit like a hoppy, drinkable porter.

Bottle courtesy of rlgk. Pours pretty much black with a small dark mocha head that leaves lots of spotty trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is malty, tiny fruity and slightly herbal with roasted malts, caramel, toffee, grapefruit juice, mango, peaches, dark roast coffee, liquorice, moist soil and lemon zest. Taste is tiny sweet, bitter, malty, tiny fruity and herbal. Mouthfeel is soft, tiny dry, astringent and medium bodied. Finish is tiny sweet and bitter with roasted malts, dark roast coffee and grapefruit. Solid BIPA. Nothing extreme.
A: Pitch black with a light brown colour N: Coffee, plum, floral, caramel T: Coffee, floral O: Quite burned flavour. Nice though!

Sample at The Trillium and Tree House-tasting in Kville, Göteborg. Dark almost black beer with a nice beige head. Hoppy chocolate aroma, cocoa, tar, citrusy hops, licorice, some soot. Roasted chocolate flavor, citrus, grapes, licorice, piney hops, some grass. Quite nice.
Pours black with a nice tanned head. Aroma is roasted malty sweet ashy chocolate coffee hoppy. Flavor is bitter fruity nicely dark slightly sweet and finishes longlived bitter roasted.

Bottle @ Benzai, medium sample. Dark brown color, medium frothy brown head. Aroma of fruity hops, grapefruit, bit pine, fair amount of roast, dark chocolate. Getting towards a hoppy porter almost with the choc and roast. Medium bitter in taste, nicely balanced between roasty bitterness and hoppy bitterness. Slight hint of licorice. Good balance, good beer.

Bottle [from trade with Abitker] @ home shared with Caesar. Opaque dark brown to black color, full sized brown colored head. Both aroma and flavor are a very nice mix of malts, lightly chocolate malts, roast and hops. Malts and hops blended together incredibly well, perfectly balanced. Medium body and suitable carbonation. Rightfully in the Black IPA top 50 if you ask me.

Aroma: roasty, chocolate, citrus, 
Appearance: black with a tan head
Taste: medium sweetness, medium bitterness, 
Palate: lmedium body, slick feel, average carbonation, bitter finish

Delicious

Ahhh another superbly crafted brew from MBC. Dark slick and lucious. nose of black patent malt, some hops and oysters. Same keeps with body but hops abound and oyster fades to mellow. Chocolate replaces. Yum

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2016 Embouteillée le 19/01/2016, bue après 2 mois. Robe noire opaque surmonté dun beau col de mousse blanchâtre dense, collant et laiteux. Arômes de malt rôti, café, agrumes, pointes de chocolat noir, léger poivre. Le nez est superbe. Un équilibre presque sans faille entre les deux styles. Cest frais et leger. En bouche, on reste dans le malt rôti et les agrumes (pamplemousse et orange surtout). Suivent ensuite le chocolat noir, un peu de noix grillées, grains de café. Larrière-goût laisse une petite sensation de fumée/cendre. La finale est plutôt amère et où se sont les houblons qui dominent avec un soupçon de café. Texture laiteuse et corps moyen. Excellente black ipa et ma meilleure bière de MB après quelques "déceptions".

A citrusy take on an already pretty novel style. Theres a lot of characteristic bright, bold Maine Beer Co. hop flavor in this beer, with citrus and pine dominating, and the roasted notes create a lot of flavor before finishing refreshing and dry. Mighty fine.

Bottle. Moderate aromas of dark bread and coffee for the malt, resin for the hops, earth for the yeast, with background notes of tar, wood, tobacco and a hint of whiskey. Head is small, frothy, light tan, with some spots of lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is very dark brown. Flavor starts slightly sweet and lightly to moderately acidic, then finishes lightly acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is medium, watery, with a lively carbonation. Nice deep aromas and flavors in this top notch Black IPA.

Pours a dark chestnut brown color that appears pitch black and completely opaque in the glass without even the slightest hint if lighter color. Theres a two finger, frothy beige head that very slowly settles into a thick, lasting ring. Very good retention with streaks of soapy lacing coating the glass on the way down. 

Dank, earthy aroma with prominent resinous, oily hops along with grassy pine needle, a touch of citrus and a slightly smokey, dark malt backbone. Underneath the earthy hops, the smokey element of the malt bill gives off a very subtle phenolic presence but it isnt very distracting or unpleasant. Some liquid smoke and charcoal along with dark chocolate, oatmeal, robust coffee bean and sweeter, dessert-like malt character. The malts begin to overpower the hops as it warms but the nose remains complex and inviting. 

On the fuller end of medium body with slight viscosity and soft carbonation. Very dry and bitter up front with the earthy hops and charred malt flavors playing off of each other. Strong sticky, resinous hop flavor up front with grass, pine and spruce tip but its missing the subtle citrus presence found in the nose. The hops are countered by a deeply roasted dark malt backbone that is somewhat acrid and nearly burnt tasting. The smoke presence is a bit stronger than in the aroma with hints of ash, charcoal and burnt toast along with used coffee grinds, oatmeal and dark chocolate. This beer has a decent balance of hops and malt but tastes very one dimensional with a ton of tongue scraping, dry bitterness and overwhelming roast. Needs a lot more sweetness to balance things out. Overall, this isnt a terrible beer but its boring, a bit harsh and tough to drink.
Draft at Hopleaf. Pours black with small tan head. Nose and taste is coffee, chocolate with hop bitterness. One of the better black IPAs.

Expecting a hefe based on the name. Oops. Pours very dark brown with cream head. Nose of Sani-clean per the brothers in law. Hops mixed with dark cocoa. In the mouth similar. Finish with dry chocolate,a touch of bitter. Quite nice.

A deep dark black ipa with a super luscious thick frothy brown head. In aroma, sweet fruity chocolate malt with coffee grind, musty floral hops, grapefruit pulp, very fragrant. In mouth, a nice bitter sweet chocolate with coffee grind, musty character, resinous floral hops with citrusy notes, predominantly bitter chocolate. Bottle dated 08-06-2013. Excellent condition.

Bottle from Rick G. of Lardo. Colour...onyx black with a thick tan head. Nose...very hoppy while also being very roasty toasty. Palate...frothy, bitter, and roasty with ashen chocolate, burnt wheat toast and hop dust. The mid palate is quite bitter and the finish is quite dry and long.
On tap at The Owl Bar in Brooklyn. Pours black with a brown head and aroma of hops and citrus. Taste is of hops, citrus, roasted malt, and pine notes into the bitter, dry finish. Delicious black IPA
Pours black with an off white head. Strong grass hop aroma. Taste is a good balance of roast and hops. Really dry. Sensing a pattern at this point in their beers.

Thick and dark, not highlights seen. Thick tan head, thick retention and lace. Smell was meh. Hoppy and malty, weird, unappetizing. Palate and taste totally works though and saves this. Thick palate ends with an explosion of chocolate.

Deep dark pour with clingy brown foam. Aromas of cedar, smoke, and malt. Flavors are mellow and extremely balanced. Nice toastiness, combined with mild hop citrus/pine, and slight smoky hint. Great dark ale, incredibly smooth.

Poured from a 500 mL bottle poured into Spiegelau stemmed glass. Appearance is deep dark brown with a good khaki head that lingers. Aroma is toasty roasted grains, burnt caramel; citrus, pine and slight dank. Taste is roasted grains, coffee, caramel and slight earthy smokiness. Palate is medium body, creamy feel. Overall a great beer, good all around combination of flavors and aromas and texture.

Pours black with a finger of tan head. Aroma of citrus, grapefruit, light chocolate, coffee. Taste is balanced hoppy and coffee bitter with a mellow sweet chocolate finish that ends in roasted coffee. Light, smooth body with soft carbonation. One of the best black IPAs Ive had.
Pours black with thick tan head. Has a sweet citrus, cocoa, and coffee aroma. Has a strong flavor of citrus hops, pine, malt, coffee, and chocolate. Leaves a lingering bitter hop taste.

Pours like stout; thick, black, and buried in frothy cappuccino-colored foam. Excellent retention. Nose is an immediate reminder that this is NOT a stout, but an IPA. Citrus hop nose with bold roasted grain notes. Taste is bitter and fades off to a burnt grain finish. Medium body. Lively carbonation. Delicious brew!

Bottle from thepatrickman-thanks! Opaque black brown with lots of carbonation. Medium body. Nose is roast charred malts, coffee, resinous hops. Bitter pine, dark and burnt roast malts. Nails it for the style for me. About 3 months of age on this one and still loads of bitter hops on the finish. Fresh might have been too much for me.
Bottle. Pours a dark brown with beige head leaving sticky lacing. The aroma is roast, grass and spruce. Medium mouth, strong roast, citrus, light bitter finish, good.
Draught. This is a rock solid black lager from ME Beer CO. was super excited to see it on draught in VA.

bottle, from Maine Beer Company, 042815 date on bottle. Good aroma, sweet, roasty. citrus, on the orange side and roasted malts. clean dark orangy brown color. good head and lace. Bitter sweet flavor. Medium body, thick creamy mouthfeel, bitter roasted finish. Thats nice. real good roast, hops mix. flavor best part, IMO,
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Bottle from Charles St Liquors, Boston. Roasty burnt licorice and citrus aroma. Surprisingly smooth chocolate, roasty, bitter taste with citrus notes and a bitter finish. Very nice.

Pint bottle from Andersonville wine and spirits. Pour is extremely dark brown with a huge brown head. More lacing than Im used to. Aroma is pine hops on the front with a beautiful chocolate and caramel back. Truly exceptional smell. A bit more alcohol in the first sip than I wanted. Pine and molasses with some Bourbon barrel. This is good, but the nose deserves more flavor. Would drink again, happily.

Hop aroma is moderate with a citrus pine character, but is overpowered by notes of chocolate and coffee. Flavor has an acidic bite with again notes of citrus and pine hops with chocolate notes. Mouthfeel is medium light with medium carbonation. There is an astringency noticeable on the backend. Overall, the roasted malts are a little too strong and there is an unpleasant acidic bite to the beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from WF, Cville. Deep brown pour with an elegant creamy tan head. Maine have some of the best looking beers in the business. Nose is rich and inviting. Peppery hops. Pine. Hints of mandarin orange. Muscular espresso and dark cocoa provide depth. The flavor is wonderfully balanced, nuanced. Rich creamy malty sweetness cut by citrus hoppiness. Woody, dry finish. Medium body, somewhat oily. Effervescent carbonation. A real winner.
Bottle, citrus hops and malty notes on the aroma, very thick black ipa with chocolate and malts, great beer, very thick
Tap @ Blue Goat. Very dark with creamy mocha head and lots of lacing. Dank, earthy, roasty, piney and citric. Funky bitter then dry and roasty.

Bottle. Pours deep brown/black, big tan head. Little retention/some lace. Aroma of dark chocolate, espresso, pine, light citrus, roast. Taste is moderately bitter, espresso, pine, citrus, light roast/smoke, chocolate. Palate is slick, oily, bitter finish.
Another strong offering from Maine Beer; good standard 'beer' smell but nothing that stood out. Same with the flavor, but part of that is not my overall favorite style right now
Very lightly carbonated. Moderate roast, but its there. Low bitterness. Id enjoy drinking a few of these.

Dark brown/black color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, coffee, pine hops, & citrus; Flavor of slight roasted malt, caramel, chocolate, pine hops, some coffee, and citrus; Finish is bitter; Nicely balanced; Very nice.
Good black ipa, the extra malt gives balance to the hops, giving a well balanced beer

Bottle. Pours black with good tan head. Incredible tropical nose - all the papaya pineapple and orange in the world with a bit of smokey coffee and leather too. Taste gives that tropical fruit blast along with some deeper citrus and some stickier resin. Coffee and light char rises, but stays as a frame rather than letting this get to "hoppy stout" territory. More juice comes out towards the finish, with strong citrus and pine. Light coffee, roast and citrus linger. Incredible stuff.

Very misleading label, dont read the bottle label and purchase thinking you are buying an American IPA. Label states, "Hoppy and roasty American IPA, brewed as the dark-colored counterpart to Another One (both beers incorporate the exact same kettle and dry hopping schedule)." Label should state this is basically a porter. If that is your sort of beer this is probably a very good beer. This beer tastes incredibly smoky and nothing like an American IPA. I love Maine Beer Lunch and expect a lot out of this brewery, but this was an extremely disappointing experience.

Pours pitch black with a two finger foamy tan head with excelllent lacing. Aroma is of citrus, pine, roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, grassy hops, sweet malts, and some light burnt woody note. Taste is ,citrus, roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, molasses, pine, sweet malts, pine, grassy hops, rye bread, and some light burnt wood. Has a medium body with a pretty creamy mouthfeel and a semi-moderately bitter, semi dry, medium-long finish. Overall, a very tasty, well balanced black IPA from a a brewer that continues to impress me.
Aroma is dank, fruity, roasted malt. Flavor is citrus, dank, pine, pungent fruit, dark chocolate accents, dry roast/ nutty on the finish. Unbelievably well balanced and delicious.
Draught. Inky black with small foamy chocolate colored head, floral hops aroma, bitter roasted malt taste, medium carbonation, full body, long bitter finish. Nice and strong brew.

Draft at Moriartys. Opaque black pour with a scattering of tan foam. Slight scattered lace. Very dark chocolate covered orange peels. Bit of cold coffee. Slight molasses sweetness. Liquorice. Cigar burns on a black vinyl jacket. Burnt shiitake mushrooms. Some lingering glossiness in the finish. Medium body. Pretty good, but feels more like a hoppy porter/scotch ale than a Black IPA.

Bottle. Black, light tan head. Dark, dry roasted malts, and citrus/pine hops. Really nice balance, and while the flavor adds a good bittersweet chocolate note, it comes through as a little more dilute than delicate. Quite tasty, but not quite there yet.

Bottle: Same hop bill as "Another One", only with dark malts. Very deep brown pour, dark-ruby tinted edges. A cappuccino colored foam sits on top; long-lasting, clumpy, & thick. Heavy hop aroma, as expected; pine, citrus peel, wet grass, herbal spice, bitter orange rind. Only this time, theres a nice background of dense cacao bean, chocolate malt, & moderate roast. Nice woodsy essence on the palate. Dry cocoa powder, charred nuttiness, roasted malt, pine, grapefruit rind, tangerine peel, & a strong, herbal & leafy hop twang. Hop abrasion & bitterness is mellowed by the darker malts, which also add a mild creaminess to the body. Aftertaste of wood, nuts, roast, & mild pine. Really, really solid black IPA.

Nice balance between a stout and IPA. The pour is black with a small tan head. The aroma is roasty goodness with some hops. The flavor starts roasty and then the hops keep in. The finish is light and dry.
Tap at Fools Gold, New York. Colour is black with slightly brownish white head. Aromas and flavours: Fruits, citrus, coffee, chocolate and roasted malts. Very enjoyable and soft.
Another perfect beer from Maine Beer. Awesome aroma, and the hops and malt intertwine for a dry roasted finish.

500 ml bottle purchased at Whole Foods on Columbus Circle while on a NYC business trip ($8.99). Bottled on 12/23/2014. Pours black with 2.5 fingers of creamy-fluffy tan foam leaving decent lacing. AROMA of fresh bright hops with notes of big citrus, wet pine, but mashed up with roasty-malty notes including milk chocolate and roasted nuts. FLAVOR of pine needles, big grapefruit, earthy hopts, and lesser notes of dark roasted malts and cocoa powder. Finishes with both hoppy bitterness and roasty bitterness. The nose is bright and has a nice balance of the hoppy and roasty, but the hops seem to win out in the mouth. Pretty good Black IPA. (234, 949)

Slightly smokey aromas, burnt fruit, citrusy, piney, cooked caramel, subtle cocoa. Dark brown-black, mostly clear, mostly lasting khaki head. Dry, hop flavors are quite earthy, malt flavors are raw cocoa, a little like cooked ham. Medium bodied.

Roasted hoppy delight with a heavy dark malt backbone but smooth citrus bitter finish. Pine, grain, chocolate, citrus, and floral are all present. Really enjoying this sip after sip. Well done black IPA!!!
Bottled on 12/23/14. Very first black IPA and loved the bright citrus that popped into my mouth. Very smooth
Interesting dark pour with tan head. Aroma is roast malt with citrus and chocolate. Taste follows nose.

Bottled on 11/18/14. Pours porter black with huge frothy tan head. Aroma is lots of grapefruit right as your pour. Lemon, orange, some pineapple. After that settles down, you get a very distinct roasted malt character. Chocolate as well. Flavor is roasted and malty up front with lots of hops and citrus. Some grapefruit and lemon. Long bitter hop finish. Really nice. Super balanced.
black with a very large, foamy, tan head. inviting floral and peach hop aroma. some bitterness from roasted malt and the hops with a dryish finish. solid.

Black pour, medium size tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, pine, chocolate, and some citrus. Taste is roasted malts, chocolate, and citrus. On the back end you can taste some pine and hints of coffee. Very balanced and smooth. Chewy, velvety mouthful. Well done black IPA.

Bottle from . Near black with long lasting tan head an full lace. Fruity hoppy aroma with citrus and roasty woody leafiness. Roasted chocolate coffee and some wheat tangy fruity sweetness with woody and citrus medium bitter mostly dry roasted finish with some tang. Medium body. Super soft carbo. Excellent.
500ml bottle pours a dark black color with some tan head. Chocolate and roasted malts with some easy going hop bitterness.

Black rimming Lacy brown head; aroma is heavy pine/spruce hop with subtle hints of sweet molasses; Flava is very complex piney sprucy hop blended equally with roasty chocolatey malt and they trade off throughout the swirl; feels; medium to thick foamy fizzy; finishes dry subtly bitter blended again with roasty chocolaty tangy malt notes.

Great beer, a brown, smooth, hoppy beer. I loves it, my mom and dad loved it. Just a really pleasant and unique beer with the smoothness of a porter without too much malt sweetness, and a great hop kick

500 ml bottle from BOTW (Rochester), served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. 
App.: Deep brown-black with a creamy mocha head.
 
Aroma: Lovely dank/resinous hops with some nice dark-roasted malt character, lightly smoky, a bit of alcohol.
 
Palate: Medium+ body with fine, somewhat sparse carbonation.
 
Flav.: Lots of dank/resinous hops with a rich dark-roasted malt backdrop, a little grape jelly, faintly smoky, a bit boozy; dry with moderate bitterness and a long, roasty and hoppy finish.

Quite good.

[6839-20141009] 1pt.9floz bottle. Hoppy roasted leaf and a light pink bubblegum aroma. Black body with a creamy light brown body. Roasted coffee and burnt toast flavour. Full body. Very tasty, love the aroma. (9/4/8/4/16) 4.1
(w/ blankboy, HogTownHarry, jercraigs)
Overheard: "So this is the table equivalent of throw pillows?" -- tablescapes

Bottle from State Line. Dark brown pour with frothy head. Looked like cola. Roasted aroma. Lots of cool, roast and simcoe hops. Rich and thick on the tongue. A pretty good meld of a nice brown ale and an IPA. Well done.

Crazy beer. Pours like a stout and flavors are all roasted malt, chocolate, and a hint of coffee. Hops are mild but present. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle bought in NYC and brought home. Shared with Dan at home. Snifter pour was jet black with a very thick, off white head that lasted. Aroma is serious roasted malts, pine hop profile, roasted nuts, some citrus notes. The taste is bold roasted malts, burnt corn husks, toasted walnuts, pine, spruce, and hints of citrus. Lively carbonation, finish is roasted malts. Also some hints of dark cocoa. Damn good Black IPA.

Three inches of light brown head compacting on itself like a delicate pastry. Slow to fade. Aroma is floral under which lies chocolate, pineapple, and pine. Orange. Nothing is off in the aroma - no soapy, mineral notes, nothing funky, just clean fruit, flowers, and chocolate. Body is light, oily, restrained carbonation, only a bit prickly/hot, a good match for the fluid feel. Flavor is pine, light chocolate scone, light grapefruit. Just a touch of heat on the exhale. Balanced to the point that Im having trouble pulling individual flavors from what Im tasting. Thats truly impressive. Very restrained. Very little bitterness. Very clean. Some berry (blue). I love the slight touch of sweetness and how light the flavoring is despite the big effect. Wow. Even moreso than being a great beer, this beer was expertly brewed. I wish they put together some Belgian styles with their expertise.
Best black IPA Ive had. Smoky, caramel, bread maybe some butterscotch. I had planned to try a variety of brews at the Stout Barrel but once I had this I was hooked.

500 ml bottle. Pours a black colour with a beige head. Aroma of really rich roastiness, floral hops, wet hoppiness and some leather. Rich flavour of roastiness, wet hoppiness, licorice, leather, citrus and some bread. Medium bodied and a rich, long, bitter finish. Heavy.

50 cl bottle. Bottled on 10.07.2014
Pours black color with a large beige head. Nice fresh hops on the nose, licorice notes, dark malts and pine, some resin too. Caramel malts, resinous hops, licorice and grapefruits on the flavor. Very fresh and tasty.
4515

50 cl bottle @ tiong, bottled 10.07.2014
Aroma is rather nice with lots of fruity hops, grapefruit and some licorice. Flavour has lots of hops, grapefruit, ash, some licorice and nettles. Usually I dont like CDAs where roastiness is left behind the hops, but this was good. Id smoke this everyday.

500ml bottle from Beer Culture, New York @ Varjopikkujoulut
Bottled 100714 - Pours pitch black with a thick brown head. Aroma of fresh grassy hops, roasty malts, pine, resin and citrus. Taste is fresh hoppy, crisp roasty and grassy with some fruity notes, hints of chocolate and citrus. Finish is hoppy, slightly roasty and fruity with some bitterness. Quite balanced black IPA.

Pour is dark brown , mostly opaque, with a tight creamy tan head. Nose has a roasted malt up front, light smokiness, rich brown malt, and strong citrus hop behind. Taste is even more smoky and roasted. There is brown malt, notes of chocolate, bitter roast and the hops are light but have a presence in back. Lighter body, nice carbonation.
Bottle from Binnys. Very dark dense looking pour with a huge brown fluffy head. Aroma is citrus and roast. Not as heavy on the tongue as it looks. Very tasty. Another winner from Maine.

Rating #1070 - April 30, 2014 -Bottle from Coop. 7.2% Pours a darker than Kanye black (Weezus!), with a bubbly tan head. Aroma is a violent clash between toasted malt, and floral piney hops. Taste is extremely hoppy, tempered with a pleasant coffee, chocolate, burnt sugar sweetness that disguises the higher abv quite well and is beyond refreshing. Unreal.
Lovely. Sampled on our trip to st. michaels. Dark black pour, brown head. Lots of roasted malt, creamy flavor yadda, yadda, yadda. Yea, just try this one!

This black IPA has a creamy, light brown head atop a hoppy nose. Creamy mouthfeel pairs with a rich, sweet tobacco flavor, with hints of anise. A potent combo of hops balance out the big, roasty malt bill.
Black pour, brown head. Roasty, grassy aroma. Roasty flavor with notes of sweet citrusy hops.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2015 Bottle from Winooski Beverage. Aroma. chocolate, coffee, pineapples, pines. App: Black with mfrothy brown head. Taste: medium sweetness, medium bitterness. Some chocolate and coffee. Full body. Creamy, soft carbonation. Bitter finish. Overall: Appearance is awesome, smell of chocolate and coffee is really nice. Love that even if its a black IPA we didnt lose the Pineapple smell unlike most Black IPAs.

Unusually inviting aroma of candied orange and a hint of coffee. Taste is subtle but dark chocolate, with a bit of orange peel popping up a second or so in. The malt integration is much better than most bipas, and the beer is pleasingly dry.
Malty great blend of hops - smell of burnt wood-nice blend had at the good life in Massapequa - the cost of $16 was a downer but the taste was really nice

[Bottle (500ml) shared with HogTownHarry, jercraigs & mabel -- c/o j&m] Pours a very dark brown, almost black, with an average size frothy light-brown head. Aroma of toasted malt, light leafy hops and some coffee. Nice flavour of toasted malt, some coffee,a good amount of leafy hops and a medium bitter finish. medium bodied. Quite good.

2014-10-09. Black body with a small creamy brown head. 3++ Aroma of celery and green leafy hops. Flavour is a pleasant melange of green hops and roast malt, with light caramel touches. Smooth average plus bodied palate, soft carbonation. Cellared longer than might have been wise but it is quite enjoyable. Bottle from forgotten bottleshop, NYC

500 mL bottle from Total Wine, Virginia Beach, VA (bottled October 7, 2014). Dark brown, almost black, pour with a frothy khaki head. Aroma of pineapple, tangerine, pine, and wet grass. Taste is a perfect balance of roasted malt and hops featuring coffee and chocolate flavors that are in harmony with citrus and pine. An outstanding black IPA.

On tap at the Reservoir in Waterbury: Pours black with a thin tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, cocoa, resin, and citrus. Taste is unreal. Dark and roasted like a porter, but the pine and citrus hops are still the stars of the show. Orange zest and resin are very much present after the initial wave of roasted malts. Full body, well balanced, slightly sticky mouthfeel, this might be my favorite black IPA.
Cocoa, rubber, grapefruit peel nose. Black, thick beige head, godd retention and lacing. Charred oak and grass flavor. Full body, not viscous. Very soft carbonation with char bitterness. Solid IDA.

September 9, 2014 - shared by J&K with me and blankboy. 500ml bottle. Inky black pour, smallish lasting frothy tan head. Lovely roast and herbal bitter aroma taste follows, but a little stale and milky. Average body, light carbonation, medium bitter finish - I am not a huge fan of the style, but this is pretty solid - and past its best before date too!

Picked up a bottle while in Chicago. Pours a straight solid smooth black with a light brown head that is thick. A citrus hopped aroma with a roasty background. I poured a 500ml bottle into a tulip glass. It was bottled on 7/1/14 and cost $6 ($0.36 per ounce).

Appearance: Opaque ink black body. Sediment chunks can be seen once the bottom of the bottle is poured. Forms a very large, dark tan, foamy head which laces and retains extremely well.

Smell: Pungent nose of coffee, roasted barley and dank, resiny hops. 

Taste: Maine Beer Company produces a strong IPA called Another One which uses the exact same hops and schedule as Weez. The obvious difference being this is a black IPA or black ale or whatever you want to call it. Weez is as equally good of a beer, in my opinion, even though the taste is so much different. This brewery is known for making hop-centric beers, yet theres genuine maltiness to be found here. A strong presence of coffee, roasted barley and burnt toast lays a strong foundation for the forthcoming hops. Whats odd is that in this beer, these hops create for a darker, more earthy character rather than the lighter, cleaner, brighter fruitiness of Another One. Dank resiny bitterness complements the dark malt and coffee flavor perfectly (the herbal spice rack notes are also present, but are subtle this time). Not quite as sticky as some beers of the genre, though the hops are still strong and quite bitter. Overall, its a complex, robust, and delicious palette. 

Drinkability: The 7.2% ABV on the label might lead one to believe that this is going to be a strong, hefty beer to approach with caution. However, after one swig its clear that Maine Beer Companys Weez is remarkably light on its toe. The mouthfeel is calm and soft with a velvety texture and finish to match. There is residual bitterness on the tongue, but its quite pleasant and never cloying or drying. No alcohol presence whatsoever. A versatile brew that works as a standalone beverage, with a savory meal, or as a liquid dessert.

600 ml bottle. Pours a reddish-brownish black with a cream, resilient, dark beige head.Aroma is hops and chocolate. Flavor is chocolate, coffee, molasses, dark and red berries. Finish is hoppy coffee, dry, and hints of ash. Lingering coffee, dark chocolate and hazelnut. Medium to strong body, slightly oily mouthfeel, average carbonation. Very solid product.

In short: A highly roasted and very hoppy (citrusy piney) Black IPA. Good example of the style.
How: Bottle 500ml, consumed fresh soon after purchase.
The look: Black body topped by a medium tan head with good retention and leaving lots of lacings on the glass.
In long: Nose is unmistakably Black IPA with roast, chocolaty notes and a whole lots of citrusy and piney hops. As it is often the case with Black IPAs I found the mix of roast and hops created something a bit perfumy. In mouth the beer has a full body, a somewhat grainy texture and a very active carbonation. Taste is scorched malts, burnt black cake, notes of chocolate, an assertive hopping (citrusy & piney). High roast level contributes to a rather dry finish. Maybe a little too roasted but Im nitpicking, this is a fine Black IPA. January 1rst, my first rating of the year, I am wishing myself great beer year and also that my dyselxia gets better in 1041.

A very smokey ale from maine. The least hoppy of all their beers. Very flavorful and very malty. Had this one at home

Black pour from bottle. Huge chocolate and cocoa taste. Coffee too. Smooth but still a pretty hoppy beer. Really enjoyable
500 ml bottle from Brouwerij Lane. It looks like it has a Sept bottling date, but maybe since it was in the cooler, it is fine. Big hoppy nose. Dark roast. Chocolate. Very tasty.

500mL bottle, sent from Gregg657 (thanks a lot, Pete), pours black with a thick, lingering tan head. Nose reveals dense notes of roasted malts, piney hops, chalk, and dry unsweetened powdery cocoa. Flavour is similar, bringing out a great mix of roasted malt and piney hops, dry cocoa, some espresso, and chalk. Very dry palate, maintaining a great balance between roast and hops. Excellent stuff.

This one poured a darker brown color with a bieg head. Aroma was of green and earth hops, roasted malt and light smoke. Flavor was very intresting. Straight up citrusy and green hops upfront, with no malt at all, and then a second swing of roast and smoke on the backend. Falvors completely seperated somehow. Great stuff.
UPDATED: FEB 27, 2014 500ml bottle. Dark red pour. Very hoppy aroma. Hoppy red taste. Pretty good stuff.
bottle shared with seb thx Heather and Frank. A: roasty/chocolate , citrusy app:pitch black beige head. t/p: med body moderate bitter finish. o: super balanced. I enjoyed it a lot.

Bottle, shared with Parksy, just inside the best before date. Near black pour topped by a lively brown head. Smells like a pine forest, coniferous perfumes permeate the air. Very hop-forward profile, tons of fresh pine, underlying roast malts are there if youre looking. Full bodied, very bitter. Beautiful.

text:
Location/Date:Bottle split with Dave on November 28th, 2013.
Appearance: Pours a black opaque with light brown head. 
Aroma: Aroma of light roast, faint chocolate.
Taste: Light bitterness, light roast, hint of sweet. 
Palate:Medium body, light stickiness.
Summary: Randomly saw this at a store and grabbed it, boy was I not disappointed. Very well balanced, accessible yet super tasty.

This beer solidfies that fact that I like Black IPAs even though I never search them out. And this one was damn good. Bottle shared at Atlanta Fantasy Football meetup. Pours pitch black with nice pillowy tan head. Aroma was spicy hops, big roast, coffee, citrus. This bottle was said to be 4 months old and the powerful hops did not fade in either the nose or taste. Taste is big booming citrus, roast, cocoa, pine, spicy hops. Very flavorful and smooth at the same time. Nice! Medium to thicker body.

500 ml bottle. Pours a dark brownish near black with a creamy tan head. Aroma of lots of strong hop notes, focusing on citrus, pineapple, and mango. Chocolate malt, mild roast aromas as well. Flavor is deliciously hoppy with mild roast and chocolate notes. Lots of tropical fruit and pine hop notes, not overly bitter but firmly bitter with well accompanying dark, roasty, and chocolate malts. Full creamy body, with nice thick texture. This is one of the best examples of a Black IPA Ive ever had.

Bottle @ GTs house. Black in color with a tan head. Aromas of grass, black pepper, pine, and grapefruit peel. A bit of ash. Flavor is quite bitter. Lots of pine and grapefruit peel. Hints of pepper, some chalk, and grass. Mild malt sweetness. Okay.

Aroma is chocolate, coffee, with pine/citrus hops. Flavor starts surprisingly mild, bittersweet with fruit and nuts flavors. Chocolate bitterness and a little more fruit in the finish. Not exactly what I expected, but really good nonetheless.

500mL thanks to WillRunForBeer. Pours a deep black, huge grayish head. Rocky, great retention. Nose is grilled pineapple, savory meat, smoke, au poivre steak. Taste is juicy grilled pineapple, bitter cocoa nib, powerful dark chocolate. Powerful hop presence. No less than awesome from this very talented brewery.

Bottle shared by Dr Silverworm. Poured clear black color with an average frothy tan head that lasted and produced excellent lacing. Moderate complex toasted malt & earthy hop aroma. Medium body with a slick texture and soft carbonation. Medium toasted bittersweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration.

500 ml bottle shared by DrSilverworm, who got it from sloth- thanks again, Chris and Bert! Bottled 9/3/13. Pours a deep, opaque brown with a big rocky tan head that laces the glass. Aroma of earthy, piney hops, roasted and toasted malts, dark chocolate, and leaves. The flavor pretty much follows suit. Medium-bodied, with a bitter, toasty, dry mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. Nice black IPA.
Draft. Black pour with tan was. Aroma is earthy and grassy with some dark malt undertones. Flavor has grassy and herbal flavors with nice malty balance.

16.9oz bottle, thanks to Sloth! Shared with local raters. Bottled 9/3/13. Dark brown, near-black color. Thin light brown head. Some loose bits of lace. Awesome earthy hop nose, some roast malt. Some dark chocolate, coffee. Good citrusy grapefruity pineapple hop character. Medium to bigger body. Smooth, crisp, lightly soft carbonation, dry finish. Bigger bitter taste, minimal sweet. Great black IPA. Dry, bitter, complex. Delicious stuff.

500 ml bottle shared by DrSilverworm. Pours a dark cola brown to almost black with a large khaki head. The aroma and flavor have some dark burnt malts, almost smoky. Additional notes of chocolate, earth, mild bittering hops. Hints of coffee. Pretty solid black ipa.

16.9 oz bottle to snifter (shared by DrSilverworm). Looks good; a cloudy coffee with light beige lacing. Smells good too; dark malt and bitter hops with a bit of bittersweet chocolate. Tastes like it smells, only not quite as robust. Nice and smooth on the palate. A good Black IPA.

Brown-black in color, this beer is practically opaque. An average pour produced a little more than a finger of head that was rocky in texture and diminished quickly. Lacing is sparse. Smell is of roasted and sweet malts, with somewhat of a catty, pine, and weed smell. Hmm, a little scary, but good! Tastes of lemon, earth, and pine, and ... pineapples. This beer is sweet and fruity and refreshing. Light body with a thin, slick, and oily texture. Carbonation is average. Bitter dry finish. Refreshing. One of the best black IPA Ive had to date ... a beautiful malt character like those found in other black IPAs, but with some sweet juicy fruit mixed in. Awesome.

Big thanks to WillRunForBeer! Pours black with 3 fingers of creamy tan head. Aroma is nice and roasty. Lots of chocolate, tropical fruits, and grapefruit. Taste of roasted malt, sweet milk chocolate, grapefruit, pine, and a burnt toast finish. Great beer! Thanks Brian!

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2014 Re-rated fresh from the tap at Ale House. Aroma score up a point. This smells really terrific, lots of fresh hop in both aroma and flavor. Original rate follows:

Great mouthfeel.
Poured from a bottle it is almost black with a slight head the aroma is of chocolate and barley The taste is of sweet chocolate. And it lingers in the palate

Dark pour almost pitch black with a thin creamy khaki head and a little bubbly/soapy head and sticky lacing .... aroma of roasted coffee, caramel malts, citrusy hop oils, piney hops and chocolate ... taste is of caramel malts, roasted coffee, chocolate, bitter hops, dark fruits, piney and citrusy hops .. mouthfeel is slick and oily with a bitter roasted and dry hopped finish .. abv hidden well .. as usual a winner from these guys
From a 50 cl bottle shared at home courtesy of Kermis. Pours black with a tan head. Grassy hop nose. Roasted flavors. Bitter finish.

Bottle shared with iphonephan and others. Pours dark brown with a thick beige head. Aroma of roast, grapefruit, grass, citrus. Flavour is moderate sweet and heavy bitter. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Bottle pours a near black with fluffy, lumpy, tan head and lace that protrudes from the side of the glass. Nose of pine, roast, chocolate, citrus. Medium body. Sweet with a dry finish. Really smooth, no astringency which is all too often present in a black IPA. Nice mild roast and chocolate malt flavors and piney and citrus hop flavors. One of the better black IPAs Ive had.

500ml bottle. Big thanks to WillRunForBeer! Pours black with 3 fingers of creamy tan head. Aroma is nice and roasty. Lots of chocolate, tropical fruits, and grapefruit. Taste of roasted malt, sweet milk chocolate, grapefruit, pine, and a burnt toast finish. Great beer! Thanks Brian!

Pours deep brown with a thick mocha head...nice lacing. Aroma has some citrusy hops, touch of pine, roastiness. Flavor has some dark cocoa, burnt bitterness, pine, citrusy hops, a touch of coffee. Mouthfeel is medium and silky with a dry burnt espresso bitter finish lingering to piney.

black with thin cream head, consistent. Brownie and herb nose, balanced with some cake delicacy. Bit of playdoh marriage of stout and hops, otherwise excellent, balanced brownie cake with piney, resinous end, stings tongue. Rich body. Dense and delicious.

Bottle. Poured a near pitch black color with a wispy tan head. Aroma is notes of chocolate, roasted malts, some earthy hops. Flavor is notes of malts, roasted malts, bitter chocolate. Creamy notes. Pretty darn good!

Bottle shared at the Tuesday Evening Horal Chugging Tasting - CBC Clerkenwell. Pours dark brown with a creamy beige head. Nose holds burnt wood, toasted pine and dark cocoa. Light to medium sweet flavor with burnt toast, more pine, some grapefruit, darkened grass and rich cocoa. Medium bodied with fine to average carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel. Poured from bottle. Dark almost black color. Thick foamy chocolate colored head. Malty aroma. Complex taste. Smooth with hints of chocolate and roasted malt. Peppery finish. Very good beer

text: UPDATED: SEP 20, 2013 500 ml bottle thanks to WillRunForBeer. Bottle 8/6/13. Pours pitch black with a huge foamy head that fades very slowly and leaves chunky lacing. Great aroma of fresh roasted coffee, chocolate, cocoa, flowers, citrus, and spicy hops. Taste is very roasty, almost ashy, but remains very smooth. Chocolate and flowers throughout, plus some cedar-like notes. Light sweetness up front with a strong bitter chocolate and spicy finish. Thick body and very creamy. Very enjoyable black IPA.

Bottle from Julios. A jet black brew. Big thick frothy tan head. Herbal and chocolate aromas. Flavor is grassy herbal spice followed by a lasting bitter cocoa malt streak. Body is much thinner than a stout or porter, but this one is still quite filling. Lingering bitter spice notes. Very well made like most Maine beers.

17th September 2013Craft Clerkenwell. Tuesday Horal Chugging Tasting! Thanks to Leighton for this one. Almost opaque dark brown beer with a good mid-tan head. Light airy palate with fine carbonation. Light dark malts with a touch of roast and a little tang. Light floralness and citrus. Light finish. Another light but tasty brew from this tasty brewery!

At top hops with Stefan. Pours very dark with fluffy head that drops to lacing. Aroma is chocolate malt and spicy hops. Tart is more of the same. Finish is long and spicy hops with sweetness. Mouthfeel is medium to heavy. Okay for the style

Left my taste buds delightfully confused...
I purchased this beer solely off recommendation by the owner of my local Packie.... the exchange went like this: Him: "Oh, you like the Peeper and the Sculpin?" Me: "Yes. Very much so". Him: "Ok, here. You try this. But, you only buy one. Limited Supply, one per person" Me: "Ok" Paid for it & left. 
Later that night, I decided to have a go at it and opened the bottle. 
Upon 1st sniff, I detected strong hints of citrus, pine, etc... Excited, I grabbed for a chilled stein, began the pour and, well, it's dark, w/a tan, creamy head. Ok. Didn't expect that (blame my preconceived notion/ignorance/label stating "Ale"). Went in for a taste.... Chocolate. Wtf!!? Then, topping off my confusion, a bitter, coffee/espresso like finish set in that had me pondering the use of a lemon twist... 
Senses realigned and summing it up, Weez smells like a hoppy, west-coast'ish IPA; looks/tastes like a Porter/Stout; and poses a challenge to ones' senses. Yet somehow it is smooth, medium-bodied with a dry finish and overall, quite enjoyable for this beer snob trainee.

Notes of espresso, some bitter chocolate, burnt toast, grapefruit. Taste is medium sweet and medium/heavy bitter. Thickish body with lively carbonation and a medium lasting bitterness in the finish.

Dry smoky roast taste is coupled with sustained, but merely moderate, bitterness from the hops. The citrus doesnt go over the top. In some sense, this could be considered merely a stout, but I think that there is enough IPA hoppiness to take it over the line. Body is very nice and creamy. Everything is well-balanced, perhaps more than the style normally allows.

.5l bottle purchased at the brewery. Poured into an English pint glass. Pours with a ton of brown head with subsides in 3-5 mins. Minor lacing. Coffeeish aroma with some burnt malt. Mouthfeel is clean, dry and porter-like. Excellent for a black IPA; i mean really spot-on. Taste is dry toasted dark malt mixed with some well-balanced pine, resin and grassy hops. No taste of alcohol at all. Just a real good, balanced, drinkable black IPA. I really liked it.

Taster at brewery. Pours black with substantial tan head. Smells like citrus and pine. Tastes like a roasty, smoky smooth stout. Interesting combo. I like it...

From a bottle. Pours medium/dark brown with a frothy tan head. Tastes like coffee and barley, nutty, smooth. Creamy bitterness. Low/medium body and carbonation. Smells like creaminess, bitterness, and coffee.

Bottle. Pours opaque black with thick, creamy tan head. Aroma is earthy and pine hops, roasted malts, dark chocolate, and some woody notes. Flavor is dry, roast malts forward quickly followed by rich hop bitterness and some dried dark fruit; dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

Interesting flavor: all hop up front, all roast on the finish. A bit of coffee and chocolate left lingering which ends with a bitter tingle.

500ml bottle in a tulip. Pours almost black with a lacy, tan head. Aroma of citrusy and floral hops plus a nice dark and caramel maltiness. Flavor the same with a good blend and a characteristic hoppiness of Maine Beer. Average to smooth texture. A good beer.

This is clean and fresh. Good, not great. Paired really well with clams steam southern Chinese-style.

Bottle at churchkey august 2013
Pours almost pitch black with a lovely tan head and sparse lacing. Nose is hoppy roasty chocolate lots of character. Damn chocolate covered hops here!!!! Damn! This has a lot of piney hops and roasty char notes. Shoukd be rated higher than it is. A lot of hops especially for being 2 months old damn! Hops and roast alk the way! Perfect for tge style!

Flavor is lightly tart dark fruit, moderate hops and bitterness, light malt bitterness, light smoke notes, somewhat earthy and a dry finish. Medium-full body and medium carbonation.

Look: Black body, Tan frothy 2 1/2 finger head. Smell: Citrus, earthiness, tropical fruits, roast chocolate. Taste: Citrus, tropical fruits, roasted malt, nice semi-dry finish with a chocolate aftertaste and clean bitterness. Feel: Light body, medium carbonation. Overall: My first offering from Maine Beer Company. Will not be my last. Hop forward leaving the malt behind the scene yet enough to add depth. Very tasty. This brew is worthy
Another stunner from MBC. This is more than just black Lunch. This IPA profile is totally different, as seen by its golden sibling, Another One. Drink.
Great first impression, roasty and huge fantastic hop aroma and flavor. This is great

Bottle picked up at StateLine... Good looking pour, black with a big rocky head that settles slowly. Nose of bittering hops and roasted malts. Taste is initially the roasted malts followed by a lingering bitter hop in the after taste. Slight bakers chocolate taste. Well balanced and easy to drink. Overall: Never really enjoyed this style but this is a good example.

Bottle from Capones. Pours hazy dark brown with 3-finger clingy tan head. Nose was heavy resiny hops, roasty choc malt, cacao. Tastes roasty choc malty, with resiny hops, charred malt at mid-palate, and a hoppy almost tart finish.

Bottle with friends courtesy of Aaron. Thanks man!! Pour is deep brown, almost black with a big frothy brown head and great lacing. Grapefruity, cocoa, light coffee, somewhat herbal, piney, grassy, and bready aroma. Taste is big grapefruity, roasty, chocolate, oranges, a touch herbal, piney, and resinous with a medium bitter finish. Medium body with high carbonation. Tasty stuff.

Bottle @ Armins apartment, courtesy of lukaduke. Thanks Luke! Pours a deep brown appearance with a brown head. Very roasty, a bit charred, lightly smoky, slightly minty/sprucey aroma. Dark chocolate, somewhat charred, fairly spicy, piney/sprucey, fairly dry, light citrus flavor. Nice brew.

Pour out of 500 mL bottle, thanks to Aaron for the pour! Dark black pour with tan head, aroma brought notes of grass, bread, slight orange, hints of dark chocolate, cocoa, roast, pretty nice. Taste is a mix of dark fruits, chocolate, dark fruits, nice orange, biscuit roast, finishing fairly bitter, dry. Nice version of the style.

Bottle. Pours a deep brown with a huge thick tan head. Big roasty cocoa and a lovely citrus hop note, soft and delicate. Medium bodied, big cocoa and roasty malt. Lots of dark chocolate notes, cocoa and some spicy hop resins. Big cocoa over a long quinine and grapefruit filled bitterness. Lovely.

Bottle - dated 061113. Black pour filling nearly all of my New Belgium glass with mocha colored head. Aroma is strong roasted malt, dark, bittersweet chocolate, citrus fruit and coffee. taste is chocolate covered oranges, roasted malt, light tobacco, coffee, dark, bittersweet chocolate and cocoa. Body is medium and sticky with a soft feel on the palate and a moderate, bubbly carbonation. Ends with more roasted malt, citrus notes, dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee and hints of pine.

Bottle. Pours dark mahogany, almost black with a large beige head. Aromas are floral with dark, roasted malt. Buttery mouthfeel with plenty of hops and malt showing through. Long, bitter finish. Awesome beer.

Bottle. Pours a very pretty opaque black with a lasting lacy thick brown foam. Aroma is quite chocolaty, light roasty notes, characteristic Maine Beer Co hopping, grapefruit. Taste is an intense shot of bitter dark chocolate and hops, but both flavors are rather well equaled and present something more like a generously hopped stout than a darkened IPA. Palate is creamy and satisfying. Good.
Bottle. Poured a black color, with brown edges and a huge sized tan head. Aromas of roast, chocolate, floral, pine, and citrus. Tastes follow.

Bottle. Black with a thick khaki head. Nose is roasty and hoppy. Their description nails it. Citrusy and tropical hops sandwiched in between waves of chocolate and roastiness. Good carb and nice full mouthfeel. This is just as awesome as Another One. Great stuff.

Pours black into a tulip. Fluffy mocha head with god retention recedes leaving spider lacing to crater surface. Chocolate and tropical fruit aromas. Thin with sweet chocolate and resin upfront turning to espresso in the lasting finish.
Bottle->tulip. Deep brown with huge frothy tan head. A: pine hops over roasted malt. T: roast coffee, pine hops. Bit thin but overall quite good.

Large tan head, rocky, lasting, gobyalers of lace. Black, opaque. Nose of pine and roast, hint of resin, green. Body is med/full, chewy, dry and grainy. Decent blend of hops and dark malts, maybe a hint of patent, roasty with a slithering hop juicyness to it, piney, citrusy.Dry, roasty finish with a tame bite. Half liter bottle from Beer Run. Pours a near black color with a large foamy brown head. Good head retention. Aroma of citrus hops, roast and chocolate. The taste is intense roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, with a bitter hop finish. Medium bodied, decent balance. Another great beer from these guys.

Poured a jet black color with caramel head. Strong roasted barley and chocolate aroma. The taste presented with a pleasant balance of malt and hops with a slight lingering bitterness. Overall a solid black IPA and a beer I would drink again.
Bottle shared with Yanick. Pours black with brown head. Nose and taste of dark roast, pine, burnt coffee, burnt chocolate malt and citrus rind. Medium body. A touch chalky.

Bottle from the brewery shared with Linh, Minh and Angela. Pours a black body with thin lacing. Aroma is fresh pine hop and coffee roast. Mouthfeel is medium with notes of sweet roast, coffee and light pine. This is way closer to a roasty porter with a hop character as opposed to a black IPA. But whatever.

Aroma of cocoa chocolate, orange, grapefruit, and slight bitter coffee. Pours black with a huge sticky brown head. Taste is a mixed bag. It tastes like a really good chocolate porter was dumped into a so-so IPA. Each one is fighting with with each other. Chocolate, cocoa, olive, citrus and a peanut butter finish (even though theres no peanut butter).

Bottle (500 ml). Black with a medium creamy beige head and good lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, resinous, tropical fruits and caramel. Taste is slightly sweet with roasted malt, pine, tropical fruits, caramel and a light bitter finish. Medium body. Slightly dry. Average carbonation. Good Black IPA. A tad watery on the finish, but well balanced and drinkable aplenty. I preferred Another One though.

Dark brown body, medium off-white head, spotty lacing. Pine, citrus, roast, a little earth and chocolate. Medium bodied, moderate bitterness, moderate carbonation, slight awkward finish as the malt and hops try to work things out with each other.

Bottled June 11, 2013.
Appearance: The body is an opaque black with a tall tan head that has great retention and leaves lots of lacing as it dissipates into a thick rocky coating.
Aroma: The aroma is complex. Im getting aromas of oranges, pine, mango, cocoa and earthy hints. Very nice.
Taste: Well this is odd, there is a complex layering of flavor with a good intensity, yet it tastes muted at the same time. The base is a bit thin, though not watery, just lacking in much character. Deep chocolate and charred roasted notes overlie the thin base along with grapefruit and pine that match them in intensity. The bitterness is moderate.
Palate: A bit thin, though average viscosity, with moderate carbonation.
Overall: If this had a beefier malt base then I would enjoy this a lot more. This drink a bit thin and the specialty malts and hops really stand on their own. Thats a shame really because this is one of the few black IPAs I enjoy the clash of flavors in.

The beer pours like black mocha coffee with a beautiful head of medium sized, khaki colored, medium sized bubbles that sit above two finger widths in the glass and take their time in calming down. The head leaves a lacing of fat, thick bubbles that fluff out into the glass. In body the beer is impenetrable the eye. On the nose the beer smells gorgeously fruity with citric tangerine and nectarine with a touch of pine. In the roast, the beer is light with caramel and a faint touch of roasted chocolate. On the tongue, the beer tastes of citric bitter with a light sweet roast that draws a little bitterness from it and builds in the mouth. The beer also has a light acidic pop, presumably from the hops, which leaves the mouth with a wet scrim of saliva. This beer begins as sweet, however, and slowly works towards a more bitter palate, which is wonderfully encouraging of future sips. In flavor, the beer begins as fruity hops, with sweet orange and grapefruit citrus touching the tongue before a healthy roast of coffee and light char moves in and overrides those flavors. Chocolate and light metallic flavors also tingle on the tongue with the roast. The finish returns to fresh citric juice with a touch of roasted malts, and the aftertaste is of lightly roasted malts with a soft touch of metallic flavoring. On the mouth, the beer feels medium in body with a little bit of weight. The carbonation is creamy and smooth, providing just a kiss of fierceness making the beer wonderfully clean and crisp on the mouth. The mouth is left with a nice bit of saliva to cancel out the acids, and a slight bitter bite on the tongue. Overall, this is a beautifully complex beer. It sits somewhere between a hoppy porter and an India Black Ale, with a beautiful nose of citric hops and tastes nicely roasty with a good juicy bite from the hops. Color me impressed by this beer. It is sweet on the front and bitter on the end. I wouldnt call it a Black IPA by any stretch of the imagination, and I will continue arguing for some differentiation between India Dark Ales and their roastier cousins (Weez sides more on the roasty cousin side). This beer is great though, and is another success from the MBC. Try this beer.

Pours a solid black color with a huge tan head that persists forever. Earthy hoppy aroma with a roasty chocolate some dark fruit and a hint of cardboard. The flavor is earthy and citrus hoppy with a fair amount of dark chocolate and roasted coffee. Medium body with a moderate level of carbonation and a slick roasty gritty mouthfeel. Nice hoppy porter very tasty.

50cl bottle pours a translucent, mahogany, basically black with some clumpy head that is both white and beige, mixed. Nose of chocolate, cupcakes, dried orange peel, toast, light licorice. Flavor is meaty, malty, toast, coffee grounds, some orange peel, light smoke. Medium bodied, dry finish.

Bottle less than two weeks old. The aroma is very hoppy with earth and spice notes rounded out with some a little floral bouquet and tropical fruit. Theres a good amount of roast. It is very fresh and full all around. The flavor is bitter earthy spicy roasty but well balanced with softer malts and a dark chocolate finish.. The feel is very dynamic soft and a bit drying. Super awesome black IPA. Doesnt suffer the imbalance most of then do.

Bottle with Frank and Barry. Pours dark brown with light to medium head, good lacing. Aromas are tropical hops, roasty dark malt, light chocolate, pine. Taste is peanuts, citrus hops, char, minerals. Nice beer but more "another one" would have been a better idea. Roasty malts are just played, make it a hoppy porter or just stick to dank pales and single ipas.

Pours a deep burnt umber with a finger of thick sticky khaki foam. Lots of roasted chocolate, pine, citrus, grass and coffee in the finish. Overall a nice beer with a pretty silky mouthfeel. Easy to drink just a bit underwhelming.

Draft.  Completely black color, brown head.  When I picked this one up and sniffed it, I thought I had picked up an IPA that was sitting right next to it, lots of fresh pine needles and cut grass.  Taste was chocolate covered pine boughs dipped in espresso.  Delicious.

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2013 Draft at Churchkey. Beautiful black pour with a medium-sized off-white head. Nose and flavor are fully rife with earthen loam and rich pine and spruce bitterness, hints of pink grapefruit and lemon rind, and beautiful chocolate and roasty bitterness. Smooth and flavorful throughout the taste. Not quite as vibrant as my favorites of the style (Shaun Hill), but thats a tall order, and this is an outstanding brew.
